title: How to Praise Your Child's Math Efforts (The Right Way)
description: Not all praise helps. Here's the science of effective encouragement that builds math confidence.
imageAlt: Parent praising child for math work

content.intro: "You're so smart!" feels like good praise. But research shows it can actually backfire. Here's what to say instead.

sections.text: Dr. Carol Dweck's famous studies showed that children praised for being "smart" actually perform worse over time than those praised for effort. Why? "Smart" feels like a fixed trait – either you have it or you don't.
Kids praised for being smart avoid challenges (might prove they're NOT smart). Kids praised for effort seek challenges (effort = success).

items: "I can see you kept trying even when it was hard."
"I like how you broke that into smaller steps."
"You found a different way to solve it!"
"Last week you couldn't do this, now look!"
"You've moved up two levels this month."

rows: Creates fixed mindset, fear of failure
Implies no effort needed, discourages practice
If something is hard later, they feel broken

sections.text: Mistakes are learning opportunities, not failures. How you respond to mistakes shapes their relationship with challenge.

items: "Ooh, that one was tricky! Let's look at it together."
"You learned something from that. Now you know!"
"It's okay to get it wrong – that's how we learn."

sections.text: Don't minimize frustration ("It's not that hard!"). Validate and redirect:

items: "This feels hard right now. That's okay."
"It's normal to feel frustrated with new things."
"Want to take a short break and come back to it?"
"Let's try a slightly easier one and build up."

sections.text: You're not just praising homework. You're building their internal narrative: "I can do hard things. Effort leads to improvement. Mistakes are okay." This mindset lasts a lifetime.

faq.question: Is it ever okay to praise results?
faq.answer: Yes, but connect results to effort. Not "You got 100% because you're smart" but "You got 100% because you practiced every day this week!"

faq.question: What if they don't try hard?
faq.answer: You can't praise effort that didn't happen. But you can notice and praise any effort at all: "I'm glad you sat down and tried." Then work on building more effort over time.

faq.question: My child only cares about grades. How do I shift that?
faq.answer: It takes time. Start tracking effort metrics (days practiced, problems attempted) alongside grades. Celebrate effort wins even when grades don't change yet.

cta.text: SoroKid tracks and celebrates effort – streaks, practice time, and progress over time.
